Comments_List: Analysis of Indian Religious texts, knowledge of the differences between the three classical religions of India, and applications of these ideas to modern debates on animal life.

In this course, i have been exposed to think differently about animals in other traditions, and how this critical inquiry falls over into other fields and disciplines. I also feel more comfortable engaging in conversations with those to practice Hinduism, Buddhism, and Jainism because I have a better understanding of their worldviews and beliefs.

Strengths:
-opportunity to read texts that are reasonable in length and difficulty
-strong engagement in class
-opportunity to read others' work


Weaknesses: 
-presentations happened after papers were submitted, giving little opportunity to revise based on feedback.

Strengths: this course exposed students to a wide variety of literature, tradition, and belief in a short semester. The assignments were also extremely reasonable and I feel gauged my grasp of the course material. 

Suggestions: I really enjoyed the short lectures given in the beginning of the class periods early in the semester. After a while, however, the focus shifted to us and our paper development. While this is extremely helpful in receiving feedback and stay ing on task for writing a large research paper, I think it would have benefited us to also receive some historical or cultural lectures to open the class.
Yes I would. It was a fun topic and is an interesting way to expose and educate people about eastern traditions.
